content.question: Around 1920, the number of children aged 10 to 15 in the industrial workforce began to decline for which of the following reasons?

choices.label: The Supreme Court sustained laws barring the interstate sale of goods produced by child labor.
Introduction of the minimum wage made child labor uneconomical.
The American birth rate declined, thus reducing the number of children available to work.
Factory owners advocated state child labor laws.
States began to require children to attend school until a certain age and to limit the ages at which they could be employed.

content.answer: States began to require children to attend school until a certain age and to limit the ages at which they could be employed.
